export_config_data.title: Export your Sophrosyne-Instance
export_config_data.sub_title:
You can export the complete Sophrosyne Configuration as JSON-File. This JSON-File, sophrosyne.json (name-pattern must be maintained), can be placed in your `Sophrosyne` binaries directory inside the `config` directory.
 When Sophrosyne start-ups again, it will automatically retrieve the config-file and instantiate your Sophrosyne-Instance with the current configuration and data.
 Above-others, this feature helps you create different Sophrosyne-configuration for your different projects and ship/deploy them accordingly without the need of manual re-configuration and data-insertation

success.detail:
The downloaded sophrosyne.json file can now be placed in your `Sophrosyne` binaries directory inside the `config` directory.
 When Sophrosyne start-ups again it will automatically retrieve the config-file

import_config_data.title: Import your Sophrosyne Config from sophrosyne.json
import_config_data.sub_title: This will import the sophrosyne.json configuration. It might override existent configuration if the impacted configuration is part of the sophrosyne.json config. However, this will not delete/alter any configurations NOT part of the sophrosyne.json (hence, locally done in Sophrosyne)

success.detail: Imported your Sophrosyne configuration from the sophrosyne.json file

import_config_data_force.title: Force import of your Sophrosyne Config from sophrosyne.json
import_config_data_force.sub_title: This will import the sophrosyne.json configuration. It will override all existent configuration and replace it only with configuration from sophrosyne.json. Please use with care and backup/export your Sophrosyne instance before

success.detail: Imported your Sophrosyne configuration from the sophrosyne.json file

column_tooltip.command:
Action Command represents a base command for example: `ansible-playbook`, `bash` or `/bin/my_executable`.
It can be even a simpler command like `tasklist` or `echo Hello World`
column_tooltip.post_execution_log_file_path: A post execution log file is an optional way to pass a log file path location to retrieve the logs after execution
column_tooltip.allowed_apikeys: Only the specified Apikeys can execute an Action

success.detail: You have successfully deleted the Actions(s)

tooltip.command:
Action Command represents the command you want to execute for example: `ansible-playbook -i ./inventory example.yml`, `bash myFile.sh` or `/bin/my_executable --example=hi`.
It can be even a simpler command like `tasklist` or `echo Hello World`
tooltip.post_execution_log_file_path: A post execution log file is an optional way to pass a log file path location to retrieve the logs after execution
tooltip.allowed_apikeys: Only the specified Apikeys can execute an Action
tooltip.requires_confirmation: A triggered Action will require an additional confirmation before it can be executed
tooltip.muted: A triggered Action will be instantly rejected if muted

column_tooltip.command:
Action Command represents a base command for example: `ansible-playbook`, `bash` or `/bin/my_executable`.
It can be even a simpler command like `tasklist` or `echo Hello World`
column_tooltip.dynamic_parameters:
Dynamic Parameters are the ones the have to be passed at execution time. For sophrosyne to recognize dynamic parameters you have to interpollate the parameters: -i {{inventory}} {{playbook}}.yml
In this case invetory and playbook will be asked by the user to be provided before execution
column_tooltip.post_execution_log_file_path: A post execution log file is an optional way to pass a log file path location to retrieve the logs after execution
